scenario1.title: Resolve CyberCo EDR Agent Installation Error 1603 on Windows Server
scenario1.content:
**Solution**

This article provides steps to resolve CyberCo EDR Agent installation error 1603 on Windows Server systems.

**Environment**
• CyberCo EDR Agent 6.7.0 or later
• Windows Server 2016/2019/2022
• Domain-joined servers

**Summary**

Error 1603 occurs when the Windows Installer encounters issues during CyberCo EDR Agent installation. This error typically results from insufficient permissions, corrupted installer cache, or conflicting services.

**Resolution Steps**

1. **Verify Prerequisites**
   - Ensure you have administrator privileges on the target server
   - Confirm minimum system requirements are met (2GB free disk space, .NET Framework 4.7.2)
   - Verify network connectivity to CyberCo update servers

2. **Clear Windows Installer Cache**
   - Open Command Prompt as Administrator
   - Run: `rd /s "%windir%\Installer\$PatchCache$"`
   - Restart the Windows Installer service: `net stop msiserver && net start msiserver`

3. **Install with Verbose Logging**
   - Navigate to the agent installation directory
   - Run: `msiexec /i CyberCoAgent.msi /l*v install.log`
   - Review `install.log` for specific error details

4. **Verify Installation Success**
   - Confirm **CyberCo Agent** service is running in Services.msc
   - Check that the agent appears in the CyberCo ePO console within 5 minutes
   - Verify the agent version matches the deployment package

5. **Alternative Installation Method (if needed)**
   - Download the latest agent installer from the CyberCo ePO console
   - Use the command line with elevated privileges: `CyberCoAgent.msi /quiet INSTALLDIR="C:\Program Files\CyberCo\Agent"`

**Verification**

- Agent service status shows as **Running** in Services.msc
- Agent check-in successful in ePO console with current timestamp
- Real-time protection is active and reporting status

**Related Articles**

- CyberCo EDR Agent Deployment Best Practices
- Windows Installer Troubleshooting Guide
- ePO Agent Communication Requirements
technicalReview: Consider adding verification step after service restart (Step 4)
Missing prerequisite check for conflicting security software
Step 3 logging command may need administrative verification

scenario2.title: Resolve High CPU Usage by CyberCo EDR Agent on SQL Server
scenario2.content:
**Solution**

This article provides steps to resolve high CPU usage caused by CyberCo EDR Agent on SQL Server systems while maintaining security protection.

**Environment**
• CyberCo EDR Agent 6.7.0 or later
• Microsoft SQL Server 2016/2017/2019/2022
• Windows Server 2016 or later
• CyberCo ePO Console access required

**Summary**

High CPU usage by the CyberCo EDR Agent on SQL Server systems typically occurs when real-time scanning conflicts with intensive database operations. This can be resolved by configuring appropriate exclusions without compromising security coverage.

**Resolution Steps**

1. **Access ePO Console**
   - Log into the **CyberCo ePO Console** with administrative privileges
   - Navigate to **Policy Catalog** > **Endpoint Security**

2. **Configure SQL Server Exclusions**
   - Edit the **Access Protection** policy assigned to your SQL Server
   - Add the following file exclusions:
     - `*.mdf` (SQL Server database files)
     - `*.ldf` (SQL Server log files)
     - `*.ndf` (SQL Server secondary data files)
     - `*.bak` (SQL Server backup files)

3. **Add Process Exclusions**
   - In the same policy, navigate to **Process Exclusions**
   - Add exclusions for:
     - `sqlservr.exe` (SQL Server Database Engine)
     - `sqlagent.exe` (SQL Server Agent)
     - `sqlwriter.exe` (SQL Server VSS Writer)

4. **Configure Directory Exclusions**
   - Add exclusions for SQL Server directories:
     - SQL Server installation directory (typically `C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\`)
     - Database file directories
     - Backup directories
     - TempDB directory

5. **Deploy Updated Policy**
   - Save the policy changes
   - Deploy to the affected SQL Server systems
   - Monitor deployment status in **Systems** > **Deployment Status**

6. **Monitor Performance**
   - Wait 30 minutes for changes to take effect
   - Monitor CPU usage using **Task Manager** or **Performance Monitor**
   - Verify CPU usage drops below 20% during normal operations

**Verification**

- CPU usage by `mfemms.exe` reduced to less than 10%
- SQL Server query performance returns to baseline levels
- Database operations complete within expected timeframes
- CyberCo protection remains active for non-excluded processes

**Related Articles**

- CyberCo Exclusions Best Practices for Database Servers
- Performance Tuning Guidelines for Enterprise Applications
- Real-time Scanning Configuration for Critical Systems
technicalReview: Missing verification step for backup directory exclusions
Step 6 monitoring period may need extension for large databases

scenario3.title: Resolve CyberCo EDR Agent Offline Issues After VPN Client Update
scenario3.content:
**Solution**

This article provides steps to resolve CyberCo EDR Agent offline status following VPN client software updates.

**Environment**
• CyberCo EDR Agent 6.7.0 or later
• Cisco AnyConnect VPN Client 5.0 or later
• Windows 10/11 Enterprise
• Remote workforce deployments

**Summary**

Agent offline issues after VPN client updates typically occur when the new VPN configuration blocks or modifies network traffic to the CyberCo ePO server. This can be resolved by configuring VPN client settings and forcing agent communication.

**Resolution Steps**

1. **Verify ePO Server Connectivity**
   - From an affected client, test connectivity: `telnet [ePO-server-FQDN] 8443`
   - If connection fails, the VPN client is blocking ePO communication
   - Note the ePO server IP address and required ports (typically 8443, 80, 443)

2. **Configure VPN Client Settings**
   - Open **Cisco AnyConnect** client settings
   - Navigate to **Advanced** > **Allowed Applications**
   - Add the ePO server FQDN/IP to the allowed destinations list
   - Ensure ports 8443, 80, and 443 are permitted for the ePO server

3. **Update VPN Profile (IT Admin)**
   - Contact your IT administrator to update the AnyConnect profile
   - Add ePO server as a trusted destination in the VPN policy
   - Include bypass rules for CyberCo management traffic

4. **Force Agent Check-in**
   - Open **Command Prompt** as Administrator
   - Navigate to the CyberCo Agent directory: `cd "C:\Program Files\CyberCo\Agent"`
   - Run: `maconfig -enforce -nogui`
   - Wait 2-3 minutes for the command to complete

5. **Verify Agent Communication**
   - Check the **CyberCo ePO Console** for agent status updates
   - Confirm the **Last Communication** timestamp is current
   - Verify agent appears as **Online** in the console

6. **Alternative Resolution (if needed)**
   - If agents remain offline, manually specify ePO server:
   - Edit `sitelist.xml` in the agent directory
   - Add ePO server entry: `<Server>https://[ePO-server-FQDN]:8443</Server>`
   - Restart the **CyberCo Agent** service

**Verification**

- All affected agents show **Online** status in ePO console
- Last communication timestamp reflects current date/time
- Policy deployment succeeds to affected systems
- Real-time protection status reports correctly

**Related Articles**

- CyberCo Agent Network Requirements and Firewall Configuration
- VPN Configuration Best Practices for Enterprise Security Solutions
- Troubleshooting Agent Communication in Distributed Environments
technicalReview: Step 4 command may require additional parameters for domain environments
Missing verification for Windows Firewall interaction with VPN client
Consider adding automatic sitelist.xml backup procedure before manual edits
